body:
I like this being a warning. As a possible extension (not sure how I feel about this) I think we could add the following macros.

```
will_call_example
wont_call_example
```

That cause errors to thrown if the opposite happens. That way users can be explicit and get feedback if there are issues with what's going on.
@samphippen -- I'm not following your macro idea...can you explain it some more?

so Imagine I've got a setup like this:

```
around do |ex|
  if some_condition
   ex.run
  else
   wont_run_example
  end
end
```

If someone else modifies this so that the example gets run always (by adding it to the bottom of the around call or whatever, you could get an exception.  As I said, I'm not sure how I feel about this but wanted to throw it out as an idea.

I _might_ be open to something like that, but I'd only want to do it in response to a real user request showing an actual use case.  We already provide ways to skip examples.  No point in making a larger public API for us to maintain for something we don't recommend doing.
That seems entirely reasonable. This was a random idea I had whilst walking around washington.

issue.title: Rspec is always passing
issue.body:
Somehow my rspec tests are always passing, no matter what i test (even true equals false is passing)

@myronmarston Askes me to create an issue here, and upload the code that was causing this issue. The repo that has the bad code is: https://github.com/jvanbaarsen/gitlabhq/tree/weird-rspec-output

The faulty code is in: https://github.com/jvanbaarsen/gitlabhq/blob/weird-rspec-output/spec/lib/url_builder_spec.rb

See screenshot for exact problem:

body: I think we should encourage users to skip examples if they don't want to run them, they should be able to call example.skip right? Also I think we should raise an error (failing the example) if an example isn't run.

> Also I think we should raise an error (failing the example) if an example isn't run.

That'd be a breaking change, although it could be argued that it's a bug fix (e.g. the bug was allowing users to use an `around` hook without running the example).  I lean towards the warning.
I'd argue it was a bugfix, but how about showing it as skipped and issuing a warning.
I think leaving it as "passing" is most definitely a bug.
Ohh....I like the idea of skipping the example.  We can make the skip text `Failed to be run from around hook declared at <file>:<line>`.
I think "failed" is a little strong. What about `Was not run by around hook declared at <file>:<line>`
Sure.  We'll work out a wording when someone puts together a PR :).
I'm going to try to tackle that later today

issue.title: Is it possible to disable VCR based on type of spec?

repository.name: vcr
repository.description: Record your test suite's HTTP interactions and replay them during future test runs for fast, deterministic, accurate tests.

issue.body:
Hi there,

I've just started using `VCR` again today for my feature specs. I've already got a whole list of stubs created with `WebMock` that I already use for my unit tests so I can easily control the data in order to test edge cases. I'm struggling to turn off `VCR` for those tests though.

Here's what I'm trying:

In `spec_helper`:

```
  config.before do |example|
    unless example.metadata.key?(:vcr)
      VCR.turn_off!(:ignore_cassettes => true)
    end
```

I've also tried `config.around` too, but that weirdly makes all my specs pass crazy fast regardless of correctness.

Then I call `VCR.turn_on!` in the feature spec, which runs perfectly fine:

```
require "spec_helper"

VCR.turn_on!
vcr_options = { record: :new_episodes }
feature "Visitor signs in", vcr: vcr_options do
  scenario "with valid email and password" do
    visit(sign_in_path)
    sign_in_as_admin

    user_is_signed_in
  end
  ...
```

But then I get an error when the full suite run hits a unit spec. The stack trace I get from hitting, say for example, a Controller spec is something like:

```
1) PostsController POST #create invalid attributes renders @post.errors as text
     Failure/Error: sign_in_as(build_stubbed(:admin))
     ArgumentError:
       VCR::Response initialized with an invalid body: {"access_token"=>"abcdef", "token_type"=>"bearer", "expires_in"=>7200, "refresh_token"=>nil, "scope"=>""}.
     # ./spec/controllers/posts_controller_spec.rb:5:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
```

The above is the content of the `WebMock` stub I've hand-rolled for authenticating in my controller specs.

Any pointers would be great as I really want to use VCR to remove the knowledge of data sources in my acceptance tests.
